Cycl.co

A data science examination of the Bay Area Bike Sharing Program via clustering analysis

Matthew Sarni Capstone Project
General Assembly Data Science
Santa Monica, CA

  • Github
  • LinkedIn

About

The central concept of bike sharing programs is to provide
free or affordable access to bicycles for short-distance trips in an urban area
as an alternative to motorised public transport or private vehicles, thereby
reducing traffic congestion, noise, and air pollution.

Beginning in 2013, the Bay Area Bike Share has experienced continued growth
and has meticulously kept track of its data.

Focusing on 2014 and San Francisco proper, this project aims
to create personalities for bike trips in an effort to analyze and
better understand bike share use.

The Clusters

Using features such as "Duration of Trip", "Distance of Travel", "Day of Week", and "Time of Day" I performed a clustering analysis using K-Means and justified my k using the silhouette score.

The graphic to the right displays a sample of trips, their predicted routes, and color coordinates them by cluster. The data consisted of over 350,000 rows, so when it came to visualizations I had to make due with a sample. Not for lack of effort though.

Looking at Duration

As part of my exploratory data analysis, I created some visuals to help better explain the distribution of data. I used ArcGIS to calculate the routes between origins and destinations.

The graphic to the left depicts the duration of the trip with the width of the line serving as the length of measurement. The fatter the line, the longer the trip took to complete. I only used a sample of the data because my computer lacked the power to iterate through the whole dataframe. We can assume that the long trip pictured to left indicates the customer most likely ran errands.

Going the Distance

The graphic pictured to the right colors routes by distance. The deeper the red the longer the distance the customer covered. The more yellow, the shorter the distance. Nothing totally unusual here, but the visualization is cool and helps understand the data.

Honestly, I could've played around for hours with maps. The data has so many stories to tell, and there are so many tools out there. Social graphs are something I plan on looking into soon, with the terminals as the nodes and the bicycle trips as the edges. It'll certainly help in understanding how the terminals interact with each other.

Type of Bicyclist

A very simple graphic here. It shows the route and color by type of rider. Purple indicates a "customer", while red is representative of the route taken by a regular "subscriber", or someone who pays for a membership.

It'd be interesting to see how the data evolves with the addition of new terminals. As you can tell by the above graphics, they are largely concentrated in the Financial District and adjacent areas-areas with a high job concentration.

However, it seems the dichotomy between bike sharing terminals and bike rental businesses will remain. Bike rental shops seem to offer better rates, and they don't have to worry about demand or the balancing problem.
